caption: Figure 1: Illustration of atoms at a)vertices, b)edges, and c)faces of lattice under periodic boundary conditions
description: This figure shows how atoms are positioned in a crystal lattice considering periodic boundary conditions.  Part (a) illustrates atoms located at the vertices (corners) of the unit cell.  Part (b) shows atoms situated on the edges of the unit cell. Finally, part (c) depicts atoms positioned on the faces of the unit cell.  The figure highlights how atoms at the boundaries of the unit cell are also considered to be part of neighboring unit cells because of the periodic boundary conditions.

caption: Figure 2: a) Formation of conditions using formation energy, space group, and elemental representation, and b)Schematic depiction of the model architecture
description: This figure shows the architecture of the model used in the paper.  Panel (a) details how the condition block combines information about formation energy, space group, and elemental composition to create a unified input. Panel (b) illustrates the UNet model's structure which processes this combined input and generates the predicted crystal structure.

caption: Figure 3: Distribution of the components of fractional atomic coordinates (X, Y, Z)
description: This figure shows the distribution of the x, y, and z components of the fractional atomic coordinates in the dataset used for training and testing the models.  The distributions are plotted as histograms, showing the number of atoms found at each fractional coordinate value.  The distributions appear relatively uniform, with some minor peaks and valleys, suggesting a relatively diverse dataset of crystal structures.

caption: Figure 4: Example of using PBC-aware loss. The depicted structures (Mo2Nb2Ta2W2) are visually different, but in fact they are exact the same. It is confirmed by insignificant value of PBC-aware loss
description: This figure demonstrates the effectiveness of the periodic boundary condition (PBC)-aware loss function.  Two structures, Mo2Nb2Ta2W2, are shown; they appear different visually, but the PBC-aware loss function correctly identifies them as identical due to their periodic nature. This highlights the loss function's ability to capture the true similarity of crystal structures even when minor coordinate shifts occur due to the inherent periodic boundary conditions.

caption: Figure 4: Example of using PBC-aware loss. The depicted structures (Mo2Nb2Ta2W2) are visually different, but in fact they are exact the same. It is confirmed by insignificant value of PBC-aware loss
description: This figure demonstrates the effectiveness of the periodic boundary condition (PBC)-aware loss function.  Two structures, Mo2Nb2Ta2W2, are shown. Although they appear visually distinct, the PBC-aware loss function correctly identifies them as identical due to their periodic nature. The insignificant loss value confirms the accuracy of the PBC-aware loss in handling periodic crystal structures.
